awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation in the Southern Regional Algebra Conference (SRAC). The SRAC is a yearly weekend conference that has been in existence since 1988. Its first edition was held at the University of Southern Mississippi in the Spring of 1988. This spring the SRAC will be held at the University of Houston-Downtown, March 22-24, 2024. The SRAC brings together mathematicians that carry out research in the area of algebra and closely related areas for a full weekend of lectures, short presentations and discussions. The conference attracts researchers from many undergraduate institutions in the Gulf Coast Region that usually do not have sufficient funding to support their research activities, especially long-distance meetings. It is also an important platform for graduate students and early career mathematicians to present their research in algebra and be exposed to a community of algebraists outside their respective home institutions. 

The main themes of the conference are Lie/Leibniz Algebras and their representation theory; and the theory of nearrings and other generalizations of rings.  On Friday March 22, there will be a single session on topics in algebra that lie either at the intersection of two themes of the conference or outside of their union. On Saturday March 23, the conference will begin with an hour-long plenary session on Leibniz algebras and the rest of the day will be split into two parallel sessions of 25-min talks, with each session focusing on one of the main themes. On Sunday March 24, the conference will start with an hour-long plenary session on the near-rings theory, and the rest of the morning will be split into two parallel sessions of 25-min talks, with each session focusing on one of the main themes. There will be plenty of opportunity for informal follow-up discussions. Further information is available at the conference website:
https://www.uhd.edu/academics/sciences/mathematics-statistics/southern-regional-algebra-conference.aspx

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Southern Regional Algebra Conference (SRAC) is an annual weekend conference that has been in existence since 1988. Each year, around the second half of the month of March, the conference is hosted by a University from the Gulf Coast region. The last few editions were held at the University of Louisiana Lafayette, Georgia College and State University, and Tulane University.

The 2024 Edition of the Southern Regional Algebra Conference was hosted by the Mathematics and Statistics department of College of Science and Technology of the University of Houston-Downtown. It attracted University professors and graduate students who specialize in Algebra from across the United States (Wisconsin, Michigan, Iowa, Illinois, Oklahoma, Missouri, Georgia, South Carolina, Alabama, Louisiana, Texas) and even internationally (one speaker from India and one speaker from UAE). Altogether, there were eleven states, three countries and twenty-three universities represented. The conference consisted in two plenary talks by (Teking of the University of Georgia and Cahn from Tulane) and twenty-five contributed talks. The talks, whose topics were all from different areas of algebra, were for the most part about the speakers' recent works. There were thirty-eight participants to the conference.
The SRAC 2024 was structured as follows. On Friday March 22, the conference kicked off at 1:00PM and a single session of 25-min talks on topics in algebra took place until 5pm. On Saturday March 23, the conference started at 8:00AM with an hour-long plenary session on Leibniz algebras and the rest of the day  was split into two parallel sessions of 25-min talks, with each session focusing on one of the main themes. On Sunday March 24, the conference will start at 8:00AM with an hour-long plenary session on the special groups on finite fields and error-correcting codes. After this, there were three more 25-min talks and teh conference ended at 11am with a planning meeting for the futire editions. 
Most of the talks were on authors published works or work in progress that would be published. The conference also fostered a lot of collaboration as the speakers discussed informally during the various breaks. It strengthened collaboration among algebraists in the region golf coast region and beyond. The conference saw Increased participation at SRAC meetings from graduate students, early career mathematicians, minorities, and researchers at undergraduate institutions.

Nearly all the speakers received support from the NSF grant that we were awarded to cover their expenses (travel and hotel).
